config.question: How is inner city poverty related to urban decentralization in the United States?

choices.content: As the poor moved away from central cities, many wealthy people remained there in a trend known as urban decentralization.
Poverty rates increased in central cities in the 1950s. Cities began creating incentives to encourage poor people to move elsewhere. These policies were the beginning of urban decentralization.

With urban decentralization, many U.S. cities lost higher-income taxpayers to the suburbs. But the poor remained in central cities, so that these areas often fell into decline and poverty rates went up.
Inner city poverty led to the decline of cities. As cities fell into disrepair, new cities sprang up in previously undeveloped areas. This is known as urban decentralization.
